entry.content:
Web accessibility is just one piece of the accessibility pie but we're attuned to its importance. The next thing though is how do we use tools to help build more accessible things and remediate what we already have?

Prelab / in class doing

Let's install the WAVE Evaluation Tool  and Lighthouse plugins for Chrome / Firefox.

Let's work through some accessibility issues in a code pen to get some basics down

Codepen: https://stackblitz.com/edit/a11y-issues?file=index.html

Let's check out these websites and read through the Lighthouse score and WAVE  to understand issues and see what real reports look and feel like

  • https://revenuedata.doi.gov/  - Government website built in React
  • https://psu.edu - Penn state (dun, dun, dunnnnnn)
  • https://btopro.com/  - personal blog hosted on gh-pages
  • https://oer.hax.psu.edu/hlp5129/sites/fish-ai-in-video-games/reflection-future-push  - Classmate's HAXcms site
  • https://archive.org/index.php  - Internet Archive

Lab Scenario

You are a consultant bring brought in to help out a web team organized by someone with your exact name , that has a site builder with the same name , and oddly a developer also with... the same name (weird..)! You work at A11y for All inc (great company name...) and you are here because of concerns by the web team that past projects were not correctly audited for performance and accessibility. (WTF?! WHY DIDN'T THE INSTRUCTOR TELL US TO AUDIT OUR STUFF ALONG THE WAY).

Your CEO, Admiral Akbar is piiiiiiiiiiiist

"It's ok though CEO Akbar", you assure the CEO, "you're paying our exorbitant rates to solve this problem for you. We'll even teach your team how to solve these problems to avoid issues in the future!"

Lab what to do

  • Audit any of the past CMS projects using Lighthouse and WAVE
  • If there's anything simple in content that you can fix, remediate it, but the goal here is understanding how to interpret the reports and explain how the problems found can be remediated.
  • Use your past HAXcms site to add a page of content with screenshots of your lighthouse scores
  • On that page, put your video explaining the following..

Video what to cover

For your video I want you to explain how you ran an accessibility and performance audit of a website . This can be one of the websites your worked on in class OR (and probably more meaningful) perform this audit on a club, organization or other website that's associated with you or that you can actually have an impact on by running this audit and providing feedback.

Make sure to explain what the audit is, why it's important, and then a bit about how the site can leverage the scores to make improvements. Don't just say "it needs to improve accessibility" take at least one of the points and explain what a remediation would look like in order to improve. This can be from the WAVE or Lighthouse feedback.

Submission Rubric

Ran reports and posted screenshots to HAXcms site (4 pts)

Recorded a video accurately explaining what the reports generate and how they are useful (6 pts)

10 point lab

Post link to page in HAXcms site with the video included in #lab11-accessibility

entry.title: Lab 9 - Drupal again
entry.summary: Drupal was both challenging and many wanted to learn more. As it's a much more complex system then the other CMSs we're covering, we're going to dedicate an additional class period JUST to doing more
entry.content:
Drupal was both challenging and many wanted to learn more. As it's a much more complex system then the other CMSs we're covering, we're going to dedicate an additional class period JUST to doing more with Drupal.

For this lab we're going for technique and comprehension of what's happening with Drupal and in a use-case that's treating our website like an API.

We're going to build on the last lab where we started making a course schedule. Let's imagine that we're building a course scheduling system that is actually usable by humans (stretching your imagination, I know but stick with me, it's possible).

Lab Context (purely hypothetical, NEVER happened before)

In an alternative universe, you are the site builder that convinced the team they COULD do  projects with Drupal. Even though you work for a marketing firm, your CEO enjoys money and hears higher education clients have a lot of it. Now that they know based on 1 week experience  that you can pull off complex technical projects in the "market vertical" and respond to an RFP from a large land grant university to redo their course scheduling system called "PionLath".

"PionLath" has been an utter UX disaster. It doesn't model user roles correctly of the organization and has poor permission support within those roles. It also doesn't allow for web services and APIs to get data back out of it in new and meaningful ways. The university wants to get data out in a format that can be displayed on signage around the university but also just to ensure they aren't locked into the horrific UX patterns they currently experience with "PionLath".

They are looking for a solution that is cost effective given the multiple-millions of dollars spent on "PionLath" and the relative dislike of it by uhh... everyone. (again, totally hypothetical, this really isn't a problem that's ever happened at a large land grant institution )

You easily win the bid because you've got a fantastic proposal writer, a cool sounding company and use words in marketing like "leader" and "synergy" and now you're ready to dig your claws into..err... help empower this large land grant institution.

Synergistically doing more Leader'ing with Drupal

Here's what we need to do this week and will walk through together in class. We need to:

  • Create roles for Instructor, Parent, Student, Administrator
  • Change permissions for Instructors to be able to create new courses
  • Create an entity reference field between the course and the room and the instructor correctly
  • Fix any relationship data between courses, rooms and instructors now that we have a "reference" field that can help us relate the data together!
  • Add an image field to our course to better market it
  • Enable these modules: Update Manager, HTTP Basic Authentication, JSON:API, RESTful Web Services, Serialization
  • Click "Install new Module" or go to the path admin/modules/install
  • Install the CORS module for Drupal - by copy and pasting this https://ftp.drupal.org/files/projects/cors-8.x-1.0.tar.gz
  • Enable the CORS module
  • Go to the CORS settings page (admin/config/services/cors) and make sure that it says the following value: *|*
  • Clear caches (a common operation in drupal for things like this) admin/config/development/performance and hit clear cache
  • Here's a resource for all things Drupal + JSONAPI as far as how to construct paths for reference: https://www.drupal.org/docs/8/modules/jsonapi/fetching-resources-get

Your site will now work with Web services! Now let's dig in and test the info some:

Get the tools to start digging into this and implementing the API

https://www.getpostman.com - Really clean API viewer and manipulation tool

https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/json-formatter/ bcjindcccaagfpapjjmafapmmgkkhgoa  - JSON Formatter chrome plugin

https://codepen.io/btopro/pen/eYYvbZm?editors=1000 - Fork this pen and we'll check it out in class

Site deliverable

No writing this week, only technique.

Add the roles in question above and enable the correct modules so that if I go to YOURSITENAME.COM/DRUPALWHATEVER/jsonapi that it shows me the correct output.

Video based deliverable (one of these or a related method)

Do a video explaining how this little API example is working by interacting with it in the video and explaining how the code pen and the website are communicating either using Postman to visualize or the data in the pen itself. Change the data / add records in the Drupal site in order to demonstrate that when you reload the pen they show up.

Do a video explaining the value of "headless" and API driven example using this and any articles you find as examples. Why are API driven applications better than monolithic designed systems?

Do a video about CORS and the security implications of headless based development methods. What is CORS? Why is it important? When does it get triggered?

Method of delivery

Post in the #lab9-drupal-again channel with a link to your site for me to test. On the homepage of your site include a link / embed your video about the topic of the week

entry.content:
We'll cover user experience and generating ways of improving the platform by creating issues about any confusion you've run into when using the platform. Open critique is the best way to improve.

In class portion to be done using https://hax.psu.edu/login

User 1 directions

User 2 directions

Lab scenario driven submissions and videos

You may complete this either using hax.psu.edu or Reclaim Hosting. Both work.

HAXcms is a highly flexible, organic static site solution. Because this is a new breed of authoring experience, it needs explaining and people to utilize the tool in different contexts to fully realize it's potential.

As HAX and HAXcms are being developed by the university to improve time on task, increase creativity in course design and help students present themselves online, you can complete this through any of the following scenarios.

Scenario: "Online course"

Instructors don't want to learn new technologies that might get in the way of teaching. They want platforms that are simple to use, recognizable, and that will last. They've seen the ages of LMSs and having to port content to and from wordpress / other CMS solutions in the past. As a result, they need reassurance that HAXcms is easy to use and that it'll be an engaging way for them to teach.

For the purposes of this assignment, we'll take "engaging" to mean funny. So make sure there's lots of memes and fun things in what you're about to develop here. There are a few themes that make sense for presenting an online course but your welcome to use which ever theme you'd like.

Create a short ~ 6-10 page online course about any concept you want to teach a friend or family member about. It could be one of the topics from our course or something that you know more about than anyone else.

Possible topics:

  • One of the CMSs we've covered
  • The history of the game of hockey
  • Big 10 university mascots
  • Top 10 interesting technologies to you
  • Literally anything. Just fill the content with memes, videos, wikipedia articles, anything that makes it more engaging
  • Anything personal to you, literally. Just as long as you connect with the material that you want to build into a learning resource for someone else.

Video submission

Your video could be about any of the following in the HAX universe. The point is to generate content that is relevant in "selling" this new technology to a stakeholder group. Any of these are possible submissions

  • Sustainability - that all content is in Web components and lives on beyond any one fad or system. Sell a CIO on the long term cost reduction associated with this platform as well as the ability to be portable in migrating content between systems because its less platform locked.
  • Multi-CMS - HAX can be leveraged in Drupal, WordPress, GravCMS (you could even show how to install it in these..). Demonstrate HAX running in another platform and submit a video about your experience involved in that process. If it makes sense, if you couldn't get it working and what was confusing, are all valid and important outcomes.
  • Your Experience - Describe your frustrations in using HAX and HAXcms. What made sense immediately? What took some time to figure out? What's something that worked really well? What's something that still doesn't make sense to you?

What didn't work or what you ran into issues using the platform are critical to our team getting user feedback and improving.

Submitting this Lab

Embed your YouTube video on the homepage of your HAXcms site.

Submit a link to your HAXcms site to #lab10-haxtheweb

Grading the Lab

Did you create a site using HAXcms and post your link to the channel (2pts)

Did you create a fun site that teaches someone about a topic you are passionate about? (4pts)

Did you record a video that makes the case for HAXcms, show how to setup HAX in another platform, or unpack and explain your experience (POSITIVE OR NEGATIVE) in using the platform? (4pts)

Special note : You will not be evaluated based on your opinion of the platform. If you have a horrible experience or don't like it or something is difficult, be honest. We grow from critique far more then fake-positive reviews. You are evaluated based on GIVING AN OPINION and backing it up :)

entry.title: ClassicPress / WordPress
entry.summary: Lecture slides from this weekThis week we'll be covering WordPress, the worlds most widely used open source CMS. WordPress is great for simple websites of which the web is made up of many. It's why
entry.content:
Lecture slides from this week

This week we'll be covering WordPress, the worlds most widely used open source CMS. WordPress is great for simple websites of which the web is made up of many. It's why it powers (estimates, numbers differ by source) 33% to as much as 50% of sites on the internet.

These sites could be everything from the Whitehouse down to every individual blog / new acount on wordpress.com (SaaS solution version) which is why people take some of that number with a grain of salt.

It's a great platform to start your own website on but it's run into some recent controversies which are worth exploring - namely the battle for the heart of the community around a text editor. It's weird to think about, but when a CMS lives and dies by the ease of content entry, you can understand why the new core mandatory text editor called Gutenberg  would attract positive and negative attention.

With plans to phase out the "Classic Editor" in 2020 many people in the community are at a cross-roads: Continue to trust the same core community that "took away" their beloved simple HTML editor, or forge a new path. We'll look briefly at the concept of community forks through the context of ClassicPress, a popular WordPress alternative that's gaining traction as the more community centric CMS.

With parallels to Drupal and it's popular fork Backdrop (topic for next lab) we'll see that it's not always code that leads to inflection points in groups but the process by which that code is formed, agreed upon, and ultimately pushed into the main project everyone's aligned with.

WordPress is a great resume builder both in terms of the platform as well as putting on your resume that you have experience with it, so let's dig in and check it out in ReclaimHosting  once more!

entry.title: GravCMS
entry.summary: Slides about CPanel & GravCMS from classThis week kicks off Reclaim hosting and our Content Management System section of the course. We're going to be covering four different content management sys
entry.content:
Slides about CPanel & GravCMS from class

This week kicks off Reclaim hosting and our Content Management System section of the course. We're going to be covering four different content management systems in this section of the course leveraging Reclaim hosting to skip a lot of the tediousness of setting up and playing with a CMS.

We'll talk about CPanel in the high level as far as what function it provides and navigate some of the parts of it a bit, though it won't be the focus. CPanel has been around forever (in web terms) and is still a powerful way to abstract away the complexity of managing servers and get you access to installing apps via a nice UI and mild technical knowledge.

Listing CMS "Site building" skills on a resume is a sure fire way to get noticed by certain companies looking for people who can hit the ground running with their internal systems. It demonstrates that you know how to navigate technical systems and can be taught out to administer them (potentially).

It's also a bit crazy as CMSs really are just big storage houses of information with text editors and other UIs that help streamline getting large groups of media and content on the web. The crazy part is, this really isn't that hard to do (as we'll demonstrate through these units) but a lot of people are so afraid of them that they won't touch them.

Master any one of these popular CMSs coming up (especially Drupal coming up) and you'll stand out in any organization that manages web projects or interfaces regularly with the web properties of the company directly.

Links and resources for working with GravCMS

  • GravCMS documentation  (Basic tutorial of working with it)
  • GravCMS homepage
  • GravCMS plugin listing

Web components are the future of web development. Combined with package management systems like npm, they empower teams to leverage the work of others in a sustainable, secure and accessible manner.

For this lab we're going to look at a few different services that are like codepen but allow for more advanced use-cases and development to support web components (and other front end languages).

Exercises

We're going to look at some different examples in different platforms that are similar to codepen but I also wanted to point out this really slick, business use-case demo from a popular web components company named Vaadin: https://demo.vaadin.com/customer-crud-app/

  • https://glitch.com/~ui5-webcomponents
  • https://glitch.com/edit/#!/wcp-model-viewer?path=index.html:27:28

Stackblitz.com - An example of three different web component libraries achieving the same result through similar syntax:  https://stackblitz.com/edit/govsummit

Webcomponents.dev - A Headless web application example:  https://webcomponents.dev/edit/nBDd1nHi5clvN1QAdSys

How to submit to lab

Similar to last week, we're going to fork and modify something but then we have a specific type of topic prompt for the response:

  1. Fork this repo just like we did last week
  2. Update the details in example-app to relate to you
  3. Copy the example-app code and fill it out differently, demonstrating stacking / time savings
  4. update the CSS code to remove the yellow background and change the border color of the css, impacting all copies (again, scale)
  5. Do your written response where it says "Here's where you should fill in your response "
  6. Pick one of these to frame your writing and video response:
    • Make the business , security , accessibility,  OR design case for using web components, leveraging links to support your case or through demonstration in one of the repos we've stepped through.
    • Code / Developer route : Run through Try LitElement and do a video explaining the value of LitElement, with supporting links.
    • Package manager / tooling pro : Setup NPM / node and create an element using Open-WC, the tooling the pros use https://open-wc.org/guide/  and do a video on that process / making a hello-world element in it.
  7. Record your video and link to it from your fork of the repo next to the writing area
  8. Post in #lab-4-webcomponents  in our slack group
  9. Purchase a domain / account on Reclaim hosting to prepare for next week

entry.content:
Lab 4

  • Web components and "components" as in designed pieces of websites are different things (but related). Components could be like a product shown on the Walmart website. A Web component would be if Walmart used and designed a < walmart-product type="homepage" sku="3u447748839" > kind of a thing. It's the parallel to the design asset but now it's an encapsulated, stackable item that can be reused and maintained in one place.
    • This is a common misconception in industry too
  • Apparently https://codeburst.io/6-reasons-you-should-use-native-web-components-b45e18e069c2  comes up high in google search rankings when looking for a link about it ;)

Lab 3


  • When you include links, videos, images, etc in your video, try to copy and paste the link into the description on YouTube . This helps others explore the topics in greater detail  AND DIRECTLY IMPROVES YOUR GOOGLE SEARCH RANKINGS OR SEO
  • Speaking of SEO, checkout how Blake handled this  https://codepen.io/blakeevanwills/pen/qBWYKqr
  • Some nice examples from the advanced resume
    • Eric - https://codepen.io/zlstravel/pen/oNvMzVg
    • Luke - https://codepen.io/lhcyberx/pen/LYPrEXp

Lab 2

  • When you include links, videos, images, etc in your video, try to copy and paste the link into the description on YouTube . This helps others explore the topics in greater detail (general screen-caster tip)
  • Frame topics in a vacuum, not in the context of our course. Act like this is a video you're making just to explain a topic to explain it. Next year someone might care about how to make a Pull Request and learn from you, they won't know (or care) about IST 402 or that it's for school
    • Job interview : I know how to do X, I can explain Y. Less In class I learned about X,  I did an assignment once about Y.
  • Be mindful of time. It's hard (for me too) but the 2.5 to 5 minute target helps with engagement as well as helps you refine your words when speaking about topics fluidly
    • Job interview : Be on point, precise in language, exacting in explanations and you demonstrate confidence in the topic matter.
  • WRITE BEFORE SPEAKING. The blogging / writing aspect of the lab response is to help practice technical writing but also to frame your thoughts and find words that work for concepts.
    • 500 words == 5 minutes; 300, 3 minutes; these values are to help you get more exact in your language both written and verbal
  • Walking and Chewing Gum is difficult - You are not being judged on accuracy of things like "Did you issue the pull request perfectly that one time". Try to demonstrate the concept on video, live. Practice once beforehand if it helps smooth things out.
    • Job interview : Thinking on the fly, not planned out canned responses to things. Fluid conversation mixing in and out of technical concepts isn't easy, that's why we're practicing it.
  • To those treating this like a brand / identity, keep doing what your doing, many of these are flipping fantastic!

Lab 1

  • ABOB (made up acronym) - Always Be On Brand. Similar account names, same photos, interlink social accounts with writing with posts
  • Always leave 2-3 seconds on the front and back of a screencast
  • Do an audio levels check
  • Shoot for the same style sign on and sign off

entry.content:
Checklist

Before recording always make sure...

  • You've got the links you want to view open in tabs in a browser window
  • You've got headphones / some kind of microphone to record your voice
    • You can use internal microphones but the quality on them is pretty bad so try to use a headset / earbuds if you have them
  • You've authorized whatever it is to record your voice and test that audio is working!
    • I fell victim to this many times early on

Next you'll need to pick a screen casting tool to do the recording. I recommend one of the following.

Zoom (Free)

Link : https://cmm.psu.edu/zoom/

Penn state labs come with zoom installed. You can also install this on your personal device and should be able to do recordings from it. I recommend finding a quite place that you can bring headphones since you'll have to do voice over describing what's on screen and explaining it to others.

Screencastify (Free, ad based with paid option)

Link : https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/screencastify-screen-vide/mmeijimgabbpbgpdklnllpncmdofkcpn?hl=en

I just found this recently, it's a browser plugin for Chrome. If you're O.K. with the permissions that it requires , it's a very easy to use way of generating a screencast.

Snagit (Paid)

Link :  https://www.techsmith.com/snagit-pricing.html

I use Snagit personally for all of my screen casting that I do. It is $30 but comes with some basic ways of doing quick editing and image mock up as well. It's not required that you use Snagit by any means, just saying what I've had positive experiences with previously.

Others

If you find others that you like feel free to share them with the class. The purpose of this class is not to get into high end video editing so beware that it is expected you'll generate videos each week. The content of the video is what matters, not fancy intros or well cut jumps or anything like that. Being able to fluidly communicate about a technical concept and teach others about how to use it and what it is.
